name.text: 19.2.8.1 Solving equations via the integrating factor

questiontext.text:
Solving equations via the integrating factor

Having found the integrating factor for a linear equation we now proceed to solve the equation.

Returning to the differential equation, written in standard form: \[\dfrac{\mathrm{d}i}{\mathrm{d}t}+{R\over L}i={E\over L}\cos\omega t\] for which the integrating factor is \[ e^{Rt/L}\] we multiply the equation by the integrating factor to obtain \[e^{Rt/L} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}i}{\mathrm{d}t}+{R\over L} e^{Rt/L} i={E\over L}e^{Rt/L}\cos\omega t.\] At this stage the left-hand side of this equation can always be simplified as follows: \[ \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}(e^{Rt/L} i)={E\over L} e^{Rt/L}\cos\omega t.\] Now this is in the form of an exact differential equation and so we can integrate both sides to obtain the solution: \[ e^{Rt/L} i={E\over L}\int e{Rt/L}\cos\omega t\ \mathrm{d}t.\] All that remains is to complete the integral on the right-hand side. Using the method of integration by parts we find \[\int e^{Rt/L}\cos\omega t\ \mathrm{d} t=\dfrac{L}{ L^2\omega^2+R^2}\left[\omega L\ \sin \omega t+R\cos\omega t\right]e^{Rt/L}.\] Hence \[ e^{Rt/L}\ i={E\over L^2\omega^2+R^2}\left[\omega L\sin\omega t+R\cos\omega t\right] e^{Rt/L}+C.\] Finally \[ i={E\over L^2\omega^2+R^2}\left[\omega L\sin \omega t +R\cos\omega t\right]+C e^{-Rt/L}\] is the solution to the original differential equation. Note that, as we should expect for the solution to a first order differential equation, it contains a single arbitrary constant \(C\).
